awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wafer-Scale Nanomanufacturing of 2D Atomic Layer Material Heterostructures Through Exfoliation and Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
Two-dimensional atomic layer materials are strong candidate materials for semiconductor and energy device technologies. When stacked together three-dimensional heterogeneous nanostructures are formed. Owing to weak vertical interaction between two-dimensional materials, their heterostructures display unique device functionality and novel physical phenomena. However, it has been extremely challenging to fabricate such two-dimensional building blocks and three-dimensional heterostructures from them due to a lack of methodology to control layer numbers and limited manufacturing scale. This award supports both modeling and experimental research to develop a low-cost nanomanufacturing process of wafer-scale two-dimensional materials-based heterostructures through exfoliation and transfer. This technology offers unique features of enabling preparation of a wide range of freestanding monolayer two-dimensional materials and providing the potential for heterogeneous integration at wafer-scale. The success of this project broadly impacts high performance, atomically-thin semiconductor device technologies, such as new transistors, solar cells, light emitting diodes (LEDs), photodetectors, lasers, and sensors that could touch every aspect of daily life. Therefore, results from this research benefits both the U.S. economy and society. The project's broader impacts plans involve learning to apply textbook theories to industrial applications through intensive nano-engineering lab modules, which includes results from the exfoliation and transfer process to fabricate heterostructures of 2D materials. 

The proposed Layer Resolved Splitting (LRS) process enables manufacturing of wafer-scale heterogeneously integrated two-dimensional (2D) atomic layer building blocks by precisely controlling the exfoliation and transfer of a wide variety of 2D materials. The research team demonstrates the feasibility of the LRS technique to manufacture multiple monolayer materials at wafer-scale by performing "one growth" of multiple layers of 2D materials on the wafer. Furthermore, the proposed dry stacking process substantially improves the performance of wafer-scale heterostructures compared to heterostructures prepared by wet stacking. Eventually, this project opens up new opportunities in 2D materials research by providing a reliable platform to manufacture monolayer-resolved wafer-scale 3D heterostructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Newly found two-dimensional (2D) materials and their heterostructures have been tremendously studied due to their superior optical, electrical, thermal, and physical properties at atomically-thin thickness, but reliable, reproducible, and cost-efficient production methods of 2D materials at wafer-scale and monolayer-resolution have not been matured yet. Over this project, we have successfully developed and demonstrated a 2D materials manufacture method at wafer-scale and low cost, which is the Layer Resolved Split (LRS) process. Many monolayers at the wafer scale can be produced by splitting each monolayer from thick multilayer 2D material grown on a wafer based on developed spalling and delamination model. The achieved main goals in this project are as followed: i) The spalling and delamination theory was applied to the modeling of wafer-scale 2D materials LRS process, (ii) precise splitting of 2D material from multi-layer was controlled by stress of applied stressor on multi-layer sheet with monolayer-resolution, (iii) layer-resolved split process enabled the manufacturing of wafer-scale heterogeneously integrated 2D materials building block as well as their optoelectronic devices. This main work has been published in the Science, and we also have published 7 papers on journals (Science Advanced, Nano Letters, Physical Review B, ACS Photonics, and Small) based on the 2D material manufacture skill developed during this project.

Our findings enable the intelligent design of wafer scale 2D materials manufacturing process at low cost for a wide range of applications. A detailed understanding of how splitting process at atomic resolution correlates with applied stress on it is key to realizing their full potential for universal 2D material systems. Our parametric studies are designed to illuminate the manufacturing technique-material property relationships that control these processes. In addition, our project has a potential to transform the way to manufacture both 2D and 3D materials and integration of them: This will greatly facilitate development of novel electronic and optoelectronic devices based on wide variety of heterostructure combination. Beyond the societal impact of the research itself in the areas of nanomanufacturing, we have showed college-age students how to apply textbook theories to industrial or research applications. The PIs create an intensive nano-engineering class in applying theories to industrial and research settings, including the demonstration of the LRS process.

The successful implementation of the LRS process for manufacturing of various 2D materials monolayer could be significant impact for both the scientific community and industry since LRS provides the potential to fabricate the heterogeneous structure for advanced and high performance electronic/optoelectronic devices at wafer-scale, while also encouraging the adoption of exotic semiconductors.
